segments.text: The whole approach to oceanography, once the needs to describe the ocean and to find where to go to see what was happening, has caused the oceanographic programs and the intergovernmental and international sense to take on a whole new aspect.
And we're beginning to look at the oceans now more and more as what the hell has man done to the oceans?
And so we have organizations like GESAMP, G-E-S-A-M-P, which is a multiple nation group looking at other pollutants in the ocean.
The GIPME, which is the Global Investigations of Marine Pollution,
So we're beginning to recognize that the oceans as some place to distribute our waste are not the, what, well, their capacity to absorb is finite.
We used to think, hell, the ocean is so big and the dilution factor is so great and they're so deep.
Let's not worry.
Well, we begin to realize that isn't the case anymore.
I have some questions to ask about pollution, and I have a couple of other questions to ask first, too, and I think I'll probably do them in this order.
A hypothetical question, since you've always been involved in...
international cooperation.
It seems to the outsider that international cooperation will soon be essentially a thing of the past.
That 200-mile limits, underdeveloped nations being concerned about exploitations of their resources that you can't separate economic and physical oceanography.
These kinds of problems will increase tensions between
between nations involved in oceanography and be pushed back into our own coastal shores.
Would you comment on that rather long question?
I'd be less than truthful if I didn't indicate that there are other political overtones.
We first became, or I first became aware of these as a result of activities of what was called the Group of 77.
This was a group of

77 developing nations, the nations of the third world, who wanted the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission to look at their problems in terms of training, education, mutual assistance, to help them bring their technology up to other levels of the developed country.
They weren't about to listen
to problems relating to increasing pollution in the ocean.
They said, look, you guys brought your technology up to a level
that you have a high standard of living and by so doing you've had an impact on the ocean, albeit inadvertent.
Now you don't want us to become technologically advanced because we would increase the level of the impact on the ocean and the atmosphere.
So that became one of the underlying problems in the intergovernmental and international
cooperation, and I think is still there.
It's not just in oceanography, it's in housing, it's in health, it's in a number of the areas of the United Nations technical families.
What about in this country?
Certainly here, in terms of group tensions.
You know, how do you purify the environment if in cleaning up the environment you leave the minorities out?
I don't know that that is so much of a national problem.
I feel that maybe it was more in the past than it is now.
But I think the problems of the nation are such that all the groups are beginning to work together and say, what can we do to clean it up a bit?
But you suggested in terms of international cooperation that sometimes in the distant, and by distant I mean far distant future.
In terms of?
In terms of cooperation in oceanography towards.
Well, I think the cooperation is still there, but I think that cooperation now requires one to pay a price.
There was a time when I used to go to sea

when I used to be responsible for ships going to sea, that the State Department would get you the clearance to work around the Marquesas Islands, Tumultu, Society Islands in the Pacific, coast of Brazil, coast of West Africa.
And if you didn't get the approval, you simply went
did your oceanographic research.
Nobody ever really said anything.
If you knew the people, as we most often did, we would have their scientists on board.
Then the research began to get a little more sophisticated in terms of looking for oil and gas resources or doing geophysical research, let me put it that way.

the type of research that one can make interpretations on the presence or absence of oil and gas research, we began to become more sophisticated in the studies of the life history, of the distribution, the availability of the living resources, shrimp, the tunas, the other fishes.
And the developing nations began to realize that
because they didn't have the ships and sophisticated research capabilities that they damn well may be losing out.
So they said, OK, if you want to do research in our area, then you seek permission from our government.
And I can remember receiving from both Mexico and Brazil beautifully signed agreements
or the Geronimo and the Undaunted out of our lab in Miami, we would carry one naval officer and two scientists on our ships the whole time we were in their territorial waters.
And we would agree to provide copies of all data and aliquot portions of all samples to their scientists.
Their territorial waters now are 200 miles.
That's right.
In those days, it was 3 miles and 12 miles.
It was kind of vague when you're doing research in the Caribbean or off of the Gulf of Mexico.
And it worked out.
We said, sure, we'd love to have you on board.
I don't recall a time that it didn't work out to our mutual advantage.
We were more concerned about the oceans, the tunas.
They didn't catch the tunas.
Our nation did, the Japanese did, but the Brazilians didn't catch the tunas.
The people from Colombia and Mexico, they were interested in the shrimp, the conch, sardines.
But not with the law of the sea convention.
And ever since our friend from
Malta proposed that the non-living resources on and under the seabed were the property of all men, all nations.
And any monetary return from exploitation of these resources should go into an international pot for distribution among the third world.
We've been having more of the political overtones.
You've got to remember the proportion of the developing nations in the UN compared to the so-called developed nations.
There's about 161 developing nations who have equal vote to the United States or Canada or the USSR or France or Japan or any of the more developed nations.
But you also can have problems between developed nations and developed nations.
There's been almost a war between Iceland and Great Britain over the control of fishing.
What is that going to do to international cooperation?
Oh, in the long run, I can't answer that.
Certainly it does throw a glitch into it, as NASA would say.
After all, we have...
our problems with Canada.
Where is the boundary between the United States and Canada out 200 miles?
That's not really been settled.
Whose fish are we fishing when we catch the salmon?
Are the Japanese, when they catch the salmon west of the 180th meridian, catching Bristol Bay salmon, are those our fish or their fish?
After the war, the
policy of abstention held, and they could not fish east of 172 degrees east.
Well, we had just won a war, so we said, thou shalt not, and they didn't.
They became stronger and stronger, and they did more and more research, and I can remember to this day the meeting that was held, and they said, show us that the fish we are catching
East of 172 degrees east are yours.
Show us for good, sound research.
And we couldn't do it.
So they said, then no longer will we accept the policy of abstention.
The 200-mile fisheries extended zone
So far, March the 1st to March the 18th, it seems to be working reasonably well.
The other vessels are here.
They have permits.
They have quotas.
Insofar as I know, we have had only one incident with one vessel, one nation in this time out of the several hundreds that are here.
What this abodes for the future, I don't know.
Our own fishermen aren't very happy about it.
But I think they've got to accept the fact that fishery resources have some kind of a maximum sustained yield.
And if we're a long way under that, then the policy is that the other nations with quotas may fish.
Okay.
Now, I want to drop back more to some chronological questions right now.
Okay.
The last time we were talking, you had arrived at, or sort of obliquely had arrived at, back into this country, if I may mean the continental part of the country, where you become involved with...
the biological laboratory first in D.C., then in Miami, and then back in D.C. And you said that the same ideas that appeared for 10 years, it was sort of time for you to come back.
What new ideas did you bring back now to the laboratory work in Miami and in Washington?
I don't know if there were so much new ideas as they were the application to the tropical Atlantic of what I learned concerning
the biology, distribution, abundance, the other words concerning the tunas, because there was a tuna fishery developing in the Atlantic.
They were mostly the vessels from Japan, Yugoslavia, Spain, and our west coast
tuna vessels did not have anything to do in the off season.
And you don't make any money tied up at the dock.
So we proposed to develop a tuna fishery in the Gulf of Guinea.
And it would be developed with the idea that the West Coast clippers could come over there in the off season.
So the first season they came over, as a result of the work of our lab in Miami, they caught 24,000 tons of tuna.
So we achieved at least one of the goals that the lab in Miami set out to do.
Mr. McKernan made a commitment to the Organization of African Unity, the OAU, that the beer commercial fisheries of Department

of Interior at that time, the United States, would undertake a major research effort in the tropical Atlantic and that to house the people and the ships and all of this that he would give up a major lab in Miami or in the southeast and that was the job I was asked to undertake.
So we

converted a building here in the Navy Yard, brought together the staff, got the two big ex-Navy sea-going tugs, the Geronimo and the Undaunted, got the appropriation bill through to build a lab in Miami, hired the architect, built the building, moved to Miami,
The week we hit there, Hurricane Betsy hit at the same time.
So it was an auspicious beginning.
And we brought some people there from Hawaii who had had experience, both on the ship and in terms of the fishermen.
We brought some of the Hawaiian and Japanese fishermen over with us.
So as to bringing anything new, we brought essentially tried and proven techniques into the ocean of the areas of the world.
It was fun.
And after you've succeeded reasonably well at this goal, then you come back to Washington?
Is there any reason why?
Yeah.
Two reasons.
First I got a call, would I consider coming to Washington to take over as the director of the National Oceanographic Data Center?
I said, no way, living here on Virginia, Key Biscayne, beautiful new big home, three minutes from the office, through a lovely park along the beach.
The more I got to thinking about it, we had our new lab, we had a superb staff, two big ships, good ongoing program.
And I guess a little of the fun had gone.
The challenge was gone.
And so I called and said, OK.
So I was asked to come up for an interview.
And I took on the job of director of the National Oceanographic Data Center.
And I stayed there until NOAA was formed, when Dr. White asked me if I would
come on as other director of EDS.
The exception of Hawaii, I've never stayed in a job much longer than five years.
This job, I've been here now six years.
I still enjoy getting up every day, but some of the challenge is gone.
It's a good organization.
They're superb people.
There must be some more problems someplace else.
Had you always been interested in the environment and pollution?
Is that the way you explain moving in here?
You're not, okay.
The job I'm in now, of course, relates to environmental data and information, description of the environment.
Oh, I had to learn an awful lot in a hurry because as an oceanographer I didn't know
very much about the bloom blowers and the meteorology.
The meteorologists are the bloom blowers and the oceanographers the bottle dunkers.
But it's become really exciting because we have developed very large databases and information bases.
And Dr. White about three years ago said, now I want you to begin using them.
We formed a center for climatic and environmental assessment, for instance.
And they're concerned with developing models for yield of wheat, corn, soybeans.
That's in our center in Columbia, Missouri.
And then next door is the assessment

Division and their responsibility every day is to look at the satellite imagery and the weather patterns and the development of the droughts and or the floods and or snowpack and look at the implications and probabilities that we will for instance if you look right now in our west at the soil moisture
you'll find that in many places it's 40% of the normal.
Now, what is the probability of bringing it up as a result of rainfall between now and germination of the wheat?
Probability is all the way down there.
The odds are we're not going to get it.
Now, when you think of the lowest snowpack in history, the Rockies,
What's that going to do to the irrigation?
What's that going to do to hydroelectric power?
It's a little frightening, actually.
We spent a good bit of time working on gas utilization of the natural gas as a function of degree days.
65 degrees is generally the temperature above which you begin to think about air conditioning.
below which you begin to think about heating.
So 63 degrees would be two degree days heating degree.
68 degrees would be three air conditioning days.
So you can use degree days as a measure of the climate to look at gas consumption, oil consumption, corn yields, and so forth.
So we now have...
Models for the United States, Canada, Argentina, Australia, New Zealand, People's Republic of China, USSR.
And we, every day, can make an assessment through various satellites and other techniques.
Success of germination, aerial extent of drought,
I don't want to delay you very long, but I do want to have the answers to these.
This trip in Washington has been sort of a revelation to me in one way.
And almost in every case, everybody to whom I've asked this question has been very enthusiastic about their work in Washington.
Have you ever been sorry about having joined the bureaucracy?
I always come back.
As they say, no matter where I've gone, my wife and I love it here.
Has the work with government generally been exciting intellectually for you?
Have you ever had any conflicts with, let's say, the military in your early career in terms of
What direction your research or activities should go?
Oh, not that we haven't easily resolved.
No, I have had some.
No, no, no, I can't say I've had, because there have been some times that I've argued about, for instance, the classification of oceanographic data, but I must say in all fairness that the
amount of oceanographic data that the military have classified is very small.
And in almost every case such classification has been with good cause because it's national security.
There are times that a scientist, and I not really can classify myself as a scientist in the same framework as a monk or
I'm a descriptive oceanographer and an ecologist.
There are times we think, or did think, before I learned more, that classification was ridiculous.
Well, it isn't.
There are times it's a necessity, and it's in the best interest of our nation to do it.
Now, the next series of questions I want to ask before you leave concerns really pollution and the ocean.
Your work as an ecologist.
Are you optimistic about pollution and the ocean?
Well, I'm always optimistic, sure.
And I don't mean that in a naive sense.
Our nation works on almost a principle of a pendulum.
You see, we overhear and then we begin to...

pollute the oceans or the atmosphere the streams and the lakes and our people begin to react they begin to realize and then we're over here and they say okay now that's got to come to a screeching halt so we will begin to spend our hard earned money to swing the pendulum back and it's a very strange but very successful type of government that we have there isn't a
A better one in the world, as strange as it is.
So when people say, for example, the Red Sea or the Mediterranean Sea are dying...
I think it's overstated.
Yeah, I do.
I think it's a degree of scare tactics that brings results.
That's...
I think you understand what I mean.
If you can get people to react, they're going to overcome problems.
If you can't get them to react, the problems will increase in magnitude.
Are you optimistic about mariculture and aquaculture?
Yes.
Feeding the starving millions, or whatever that means.
I don't know that one needs to be optimistic or not optimistic.
If the demand is there, we can do it.
For instance, when I was in Hawaii,
I was involved in aquaculture with the tilapia.
This is an Asiatic fish that is a mouth breeder.
When the mother opens the mouth, hundreds of little ones go in the mouth, and she closes her mouth.
And the tails are sticking out.
They're the cutest damn things.
But you put those in a rice paddy, and they will grow up very rapidly.
and they will turn an awful lot of material and the bottom muds and rice paddies and ponds into protein to beautiful, clean, white fish.
Just like the carp.
I don't mean the carp, I mean the catfish.
When I worked in Miami, I worked a lot with a man in St. Pete.

who we called Catfish because he was trying to convince the people as a result of the work of Swingle and Smith that all of the bayous and the ponds in Louisiana and Texas and Mississippi, they should rear catfish because people couldn't afford the damn things.
They were so expensive, and yet they're so easy to grow.
They convert material into protein so readily, so the potential is there.
But the economics are not.
That's why you raise the pompano.
That's why you raise northwestern United States of the salmon.
Shirley Temple Black's husband is one of the leaders in that area.
That's why you raise shrimp.
That's why you raise oysters.
Because these have a large dollar value where

carp and i mean catfish and tilapia don't so if people get hungry enough if the economics adjust that's a problem i'm not saying we know enough yet to do it you say feed the starving people of the world fish protein
concentrate.
This is a superb example where we had an ideal opportunity.
One little plastic package of fish protein concentrate on a bowl of rice would give a person their total daily protein requirement.
Okay, what good is that going to do if you bring it in on the dock any place in a West African country or Java or
a bangledash.
You've got to get it back where the people are.
Okay, how do you get it there?
There are no trains.
There are no roads.
There are the rivers, but you can't get up the rivers.
Fish protein concentrate you could have dropped from airplanes in these little packages.
How do you convince the people to eat?
You've got to get somebody in there to educate them that if they would sprinkle the magical white powder on the rice or the...
What's the great big crinulated green ball-like vegetable that grows in other tropics?
Anyway, it was a beautiful thing.
But our nation would not market it, although it was shown without a doubt to be 100% pure, odorless, because the fish hadn't guts.
Then we tried to export it.

And immediately the nations who are not quite as friendly with us as we would like said, ha-ha, you won't let your own people eat it, but you'll send it over here to the developing countries to get rid of it.
So as a result, the market went shook to distribution, education, and politics.
